story:
Once upon a time, in a small village nestled between the rolling hills and lush green forests, lived a kind and generous Muslim family. The family consisted of a loving father, a nurturing mother, and their three curious and bright-eyed children. The family was known throughout the village for their compassion, generosity, and devotion to their faith.

One day, the youngest child, Ali, asked his father, "Baba, why do we pray five times a day?"

Baba thought for a moment, then replied, "Well, Ali, prayer is a way for us to talk to Allah and show our gratitude for all the blessings He has given us. It is a chance for us to pause and reflect on our actions and ask for guidance. By praying five times a day, we are reminded of our faith throughout the day and are able to maintain a strong connection with Allah."

Ali thought for a moment, then asked, "But Baba, I sometimes forget to pray. What should I do?"

Baba smiled and said, "It is okay to forget sometimes, Ali, but it is important to make an effort to remember. You can set reminders for yourself or have someone in the family remind you. The most important thing is that you make an effort to pray, even if it is just a few short words."

Ali nodded and thanked his father for the advice. From that day on, he made an extra effort to remember to pray, even setting reminders on his watch to make sure he didn't forget.

One day, while Ali was playing in the forest, he stumbled upon a small, scared bird with a broken wing. Ali took the bird home and nursed it back to health, feeding it and keeping it warm until it was able to fly again.

As the bird took flight, Ali looked up to the sky and whispered a prayer of thanks to Allah for allowing him to help the bird. At that moment, he felt a sense of peace and connection with Allah that he had never felt before.

From then on, Ali made sure to pray five times a day, never forgetting the blessings that Allah had given him and the importance of maintaining a strong connection with Him.

And so, Ali grew up to be a kind and compassionate man, always remembering the lessons he had learned from his father and from his own experiences. He lived a long and fulfilling life, always making sure to give thanks to Allah for all his blessings.

As Ali's children and grandchildren gathered around his bedside, he shared with them the story of the bird and the importance of prayer. And with that, Ali closed his eyes and drifted off to sleep, a smile on his face and a sense of peace in his heart.

And they all lived happily ever after. Ameen.
